source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: guardians of institution are guardians of Law > as women’s studies gains institutional legitimacy, it produces guardians of the Law; U.S. is a pioneer of women’s studies

motif.title: UNSCATHED / SAFE / SACRED / GUARD / SECURITY / KEEP

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: women’s studies has uplifted from repression all sorts of forbidden feminine signatures

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: U.S. more faithful to 19th century model of University than most European countries

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: insidiously reproduce the old model (fundamentally phallogocentric) in modern University > would women’s studies become another cell in university beehive [?]

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: the more proofs women’s studies brings to masculine directors of university (masculine, whether man or woman), the more women’s studies is legitimized by power of university, more it risks repressing fundamental question that must be posed

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: 1) positive/optimistic deconstruction: not submit to law 2) pessimistic deconstruction (more conscious of law of Law): radically deconstruct old model of university, not to open a field w/out law but new relation to Law, rediscover the Law—yet, no longer bored [?]

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: as members of a university, we are all guardians of Law, and also naive in front of text, in front of Law [like both characters in Kafka’s “Before the Law”]; p. 193 Law in Kafka’s story neither male nor female

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: [re: teaching women’s studies] is it only a question of strategy, isn’t strategy the real risk?

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: to say woman is not a “subject,” 2 consequences: 1) radically revolutionary or deconstructive 2) dangerously reactive

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: to say women are subjects keeps whole framework on which traditional university is built

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: to say woman is on side of undecidability has only meaning of strategical phase, the side of woman becomes the side from which you begin to dismantle structure > but, as soon as you reach first stage of deconstruction, opposition man/woman no longer pertinent

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: there’re many undecidables, one undecidability acts as a program, programming or unprogramming a program

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: classical ruse of neutralization/neuterization (of sexual marks): “I think” is neither man nor woman, but we can verify that it’s already man

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: “woman” no longer best trope to refer to these things, same goes for undecidability itself!

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: resistance opposed to deconstruction same as one opposed to woman’s studies, “something sexual at stake in the resistance to deconstruction,” deconstruction successful in U.S. among homosexuals, feminists

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: Kafka’s “Before the Law” is the Law, his signature, or signature of the text, makes the law

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: deconstruction not transgression of the Law, it is the Law: it is an affirmation, and affirmation is on side of Law: as soon as you affirm a desire, you perform something which is the Law, the Law says, “yes” (Law is not simply negative, that’s hard to understand)

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: deconstruction is another way of writing Law, affirming new mode of Law, thus not a movement of transgression or liberation

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: opposition is 2, is man/woman, sexual difference can be an indefinite # of sexes > w/ the 2, the classical sense of sexual difference, gift is impossible, all you can call “gift” (love, jouissance) is forbidden by dual opposition [see WBH in SEXUAL DIFFERENCE]

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: if gift has assignable destination, is an exchange, it’s not a gift, if there is from man to woman (or woman to man) an assignable destination (re: object, discourse, jouissance, desire, subject), no longer a gift > gift must be absolutely unconscious & random to be given a chance

motif.title: SOCIAL / COMMODITY / COMMERCE / MARKET see COMMUNITY

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: gift possible not outside of sexuality but outside frame familiar to us > a sexuality completely out of the frame

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: gift determines, produces identity of giver & receiver, gives itself the right to determine, always a strike of force, irruption

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: gift beyond sexual duality > Heidegger’s attempt to neutralize sexual opposition and not sexual difference, liberating field of sexuality for very different sexuality, more multiple: no more sexes, one sex for each time, each gift, a sexual difference for each gift

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: receiver as determining factor of gift, one who responds, performativity of text produces receiver w/out pre-existing [him/her/it]

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: it is by the gift that Law is produced, the signature engenders sender, receiver, signer

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: Declaration of Independence signed by God, signs American people into existence, they didn’t exist before it

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: gift not even subversive, is something else > subversion is a program, programmed destruction of certain conditions (relies on given conditions)

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: promise in every speech act, promise not simply performative

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: if signature, or all that amounts to it, can’t rely on ready determination (is performative), then you can’t rely on sexual opposition n

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: deconstruction, occupies both places [re: women’s studies], thus it’s conservative and not conservative

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: deconstruction [re: women’s studies], occupies both places, thus it is conservative and not conservative

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: to receive a gift, in Nietzschean sense, is to say, “I want to begin again,” not a reproduction: “yes” of gift must be repeatable from the start

source.title: Women in the Beehive: A Seminar with Jacques Derrida

content: “woman” as “truth,” as that which stops the drift, but what about truth as movement of the drift [?]
